de.humatic.dsj

Class DSDvd

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.awt.Component
      • java.awt.Canvas
        • de.humatic.dsj.DSFiltergraph
          • de.humatic.dsj.DSDvd
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable, javax.accessibility.Accessible

    public class DSDvd
extends DSFiltergraph
    DSDvd adds some DVD specific transport & navigation methods to the superclass.
    Graph building for DVD playback may require that MPEG2 and AC3 decoder filters are explicitely specified (which can be done via the extended constructor or the dsj.xml file). You will likely also need to try what MPEG2 decoder actually does the job best - some non-DVD centric decoders have problems with DVDs that change size between titles. Decoders explicitely made for DVD playback may refuse to connect downstream either directly with an RGB output type or through a color space conversion filter as required by dsj's JAWT and java rendering modes. This may both be for technical reason (no support for some mediatypes) as well as for reasons of copy-protection, which may kick in on commercial DVDs soon as any kind of sample grabbing filter is inserted into the graph (the latter depending much on the OS version, with XP being a lot more gentle than Vista and Windows 7). Your best bet with DVDs generally will be using the VMR9 or EVR renderers.
    Mouse operation of DVD menus can be problematic from java. With DirectShow renderers (VMR9 & EVR) most decoders should let you click menus directly, but some may not show menu highlights when hovered. Mouse operation will explicitely not be available when using the VMR7 renderer.
    With the JAWT and java renderers the DVD_MENU_ENABLED flag needs to be set in the constructor, but while mouse operation as such should mostly work, menu highlighting depends on decoders and may only be available in YUV mode.
    Relative navigation using the navigate(NAV_..) method should work in most cases, but whether you will get menu highlights again depends on the decoder. The SwingMovieController uses this method to let you navigate using keyboard arrow, enter and escape keys
    Captions / subtitles will only be rendererd with VMR9 or EVR renderers.
    Apart from all this, the class - despite some additional functionality available with dsj 0_8_62 - is still fairly incomplete and only implements a subset of DirectShow's DVD specific api.
    See Also:

      Restores playback location and state from the given bookmark file.

      Selects the audio or subpicture stream at %index.

      Selects the default (global) audio, subpicture or menu language with the given attributes.
      void setDVDControlOption(int option, int state)
      Sets various optional features on the native IDVDControl2 interface.
      void setSubpictureState(boolean enabled)
      Turns subpicture display on or off if permitted in the current disc state.
      void showMenu(int menu)
      Jumps to the given menu (see DVD_MENU constants) if the dvd is in a domain where jumps are allowed;
      void stillOff() 
      void stopDVD()
      Puts the DVD into the "Stop domain" without stopping the filtergraph.

              throws DSJException
        Used for relative menu navigation.
        %type : one of the NAV_ constants
        Throws:
        DSJException

      • setButtonMapping

        public void setButtonMapping(int mode)
        Sets the way in which mouse position is passed to the filtergraph when running with a DirectShow renderer or the DVD_MENU_ENABLED option set. Dedicated DVD decoders usually take mouse coordinates in display space (BM_DISPLAY, default setting), while more general purpose MPEG2 decoders may want them in original source space (BM_SOURCE).

      • stopDVD

        public void stopDVD()
             throws DSJException
        Puts the DVD into the "Stop domain" without stopping the filtergraph. This may be required for some operations that change playback characteristics (setDefaultStream() uses this internally).
        Throws:
        DSJException

      • playDVD

        public int playDVD()
            throws DSJException
        Attempts to resume playback from the location stopDVD() was last called and returns 0 on success. This may fail for various reasons depending on the current playback location and the DVD's authoring. In such cases the method will try to resume from the start of the current title, returning 1 if successful, or - in case this also fails - show the root menu and return 2. Negative return values signalling other problems not handled internally will throw an exception and be transferred in the DSJException's errorcode field.
        Throws:
        DSJException

      • stillOff

        public void stillOff()

      • getStreams

        public java.lang.String[] getStreams(int type)
                              throws DSJException
        Returns available audio, subpicture or menu languages languages. The return will vary depending on where in the DVD streams are queried for.
        Throws:
        DSJException

      • getSelectedStream

        public int getSelectedStream(int type)
                      throws DSJException
        Returns the currently selected audio or subpicture stream. For subpictures, the stream may be selected but disabled in the current domain or by user choice, use getSubpictureState() to determine if it is active.
        Throws:
        DSJException

      • selectStream

        public void selectStream(int type,
                         int index)
                  throws DSJException
        Selects the audio or subpicture stream at %index. This operation may not be permitted at all times and will throw exceptions with errorcode 0x80040276 - VFW_E_DVD_OPERATION_INHIBITED - in case (see getUOPs to determine what operations will be available prior to invoking them).
        Throws:
        DSJException

      • setSubpictureState

        public void setSubpictureState(boolean enabled)
                        throws DSJException
        Turns subpicture display on or off if permitted in the current disc state. Subpicture streams are used in menus for button text and eventually for subtitles and credits over video playback. What this method actually does depends a bit on the authoring of the DVD. For example translations of titles may not be switchable and subtitles - then rather captions - may also come as Line21 data in the video stream, in which case this method will not affect them).
        Throws:
        DSJException

      • getSubpictureState

        public boolean getSubpictureState()
                           throws DSJException
        Returns wether or not the currently selected subpicture stream is enabled, also see selectStream(..) and setSubpictureState(..).
        Throws:
        DSJException

      • setDefaultStream

        public void setDefaultStream(int type,
                             int index,
                             int attributes)
                      throws DSJException
        Selects the default (global) audio, subpicture or menu language with the given attributes. As these operations are only permitted in the "Stop domain", the method will stop the DVD and wait for the stop operation to complete, before issueing the stream change command. Playback will be restarted afterwards.
        %index - index into the available streams of %type.
        %attributes - one of the DVD_AUDIO_EXT_ or DVD_SP_EXT_ constants, 0 for menu languages.
        Throws:
        DSJException

      • getCurrentDomain

        public int getCurrentDomain()
        Returns one of the DVD_DOMAIN_ constants.

      • getTitleDuration

        public int getTitleDuration()
        Returns the millisecond duration of the currently playing title. This will fail on menus.

      • getTitleTime

        public int getTitleTime()
        Returns playback time in the currently playing title in milliseconds. Alternatively to calling this method, you can convert the first parameter of EC_DVD_CURRENT_TIME or EC_DVD_CURRENT_HMSF_TIME (when timecode format has been changed using setDVDControlOption(...)) events.

      • getUOPs

        public int getUOPs()
        Returns a bitmask of currently inhibited user operations (see UOP_ constants). If a bit is set, the corresponding operation is not allowed at the current state.

      • saveBookmark

        public void saveBookmark(java.lang.String savePath)
                  throws java.io.IOException,
                         DSJException
        Save the current playback location and state to a bookmark file. %savePath can be null to save for internal reuse only. On Vista and beyond the bookmark will be portable (i.e. useable on another machine) long as this has not been disabled with the setDVDControlOption(..) method.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException
        DSJException

      • restoreBookmark

        public void restoreBookmark(java.lang.String bookmarkPath)
                     throws java.io.IOException,
                            DSJException
        Restores playback location and state from the given bookmark file. %bookmarkPath can be null to restore to the last save state.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException
        DSJException

                                boolean autoStop,

                         throws DSJException

        Throws:
        DSJException

      • setDVDControlOption

        public void setDVDControlOption(int option,
                                int state)
                         throws DSJException
        Sets various optional features on the native IDVDControl2 interface. See msdn DVD_OPTION_FLAG docs for details.
        %option - one of the DVDControl option constants.
        %state - interpreted as boolean (1 - true, 0 - false) for most options.
        By default dsj disables ResetOnStop and - on Vista and beyond - enables portable bookmarks.
        Throws:
        DSJException
